Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: The radio crackled in my headset as I scanned the radar, watching storm cells bloom across the screen. Flights were stacking up, pilots requesting reroutes, and my supervisor’s voice reminded me to coordinate every handoff with the next sector. My pulse raced—one mistake could mean chaos in the sky. Then my phone buzzed. I was on my break, standing in line at the polling station, determined to vote before my shift ended. The election official frowned at my ID. “There’s a registration mismatch. You’ll need to fill out a provisional ballot form. We close in ten minutes.” I glanced at the clock, calculating how long the form would take. My break was almost over, and the storm was only getting worse. If I stayed, I’d risk leaving my team shorthanded during a crisis. If I left, I’d lose my chance to vote. The weight of both responsibilities pressed on me—my duty to the skies, my duty as a citizen—each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait.
